On the occasion of Gandhi Centenary celebra- tions, the Governor of. Andhra Pradesh, purporting to exercise the powers under Article 161 of the Constitution, issued G.O. No. Ms. 1321, Home  Prisons A  Department, dated 25th September, 1969, granting special remission of sentences to various categories of prisoners mentioned therein.

facts.text: Governor of Andhra Pradesh issued G.O. No. Ms. 1321, Home Prisons A Department, dated 25th September 1969, granting special remission on Gandhi Centenary celebrations under Article 161.

anchor.surface_text: On the occasion of Gandhi Centenary celebra- tions, the Governor of. Andhra Pradesh, purporting to exercise the powers under Article 161 of the Constitution, issued G.O. No. Ms. 1321, Home  Prisons A  Department, dated 25th September, 1969, granting special remission of sentences to various categories of prisoners mentioned therein. The preamble of this G.O. expressly limits its operation to prisoners who are companyvicted of offences against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the State extends.

facts.text: The G.O. preamble limits operation to prisoners convicted of offences against laws relating to State executive power matters.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble of this G.O. expressly limits its operation to prisoners who are companyvicted of offences against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the State extends. The jail authorities obviously misinterpreting the aforesaid G-O., granted the benefit of remission thereunder to prisoners B. Sitaramireddi, M. Rangareddi, K. Balaram and T. Mallikhajundu and released them from jail.

facts.text: Jail authorities misinterpreted G.O. and released B. Sitaramireddi, M. Rangareddy, K. Balaram and T. Mallikharjundu.

anchor.surface_text: The jail authorities obviously misinterpreting the aforesaid G-O., granted the benefit of remission thereunder to prisoners B. Sitaramireddi, M. Rangareddi, K. Balaram and T. Mallikhajundu and released them from jail. The mistake came to the numberice of the Inspector-General of Prisons, and, as a result of his intervention, the release of the petitioner and another prisoner, K. E. Lakshman, was stopped and they are still undergoing the remaining terms of their sentences.

facts.text: Inspector-General of Prisons intervened, stopping release of petitioner and K. E. Lakshman, who continue undergoing sentences.

The petitioner submitted several applications to the State Government, urging it to release him in exercise of its power of clemency under section 401, Crime Procedure Code, but without success.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted several applications to State Government under section 401 CrPC for release, but without success.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner submitted several applications to the State Government, urging it to release him in exercise of its power of clemency under section 401, Crime Procedure Code, but without success. The petitioner moved the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by application under section 491  1   a  and  b  of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which was dismissed by a judgment, dated 18th January, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner's application under section 491 CrPC to High Court of Andhra Pradesh was dismissed on 18th January 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by application under section 491  1   a  and  b  of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which was dismissed by a judgment, dated 18th January, 1973. issues.text: The principal question of law that falls to be determined in this writ petition filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India by the petitioner is which is the appropriate GovernmentCentral or the State Governmentempowered to remit the sentence of a person convicted of offences under sections 489-A to 489-D of the Penal Code?

anchor.surface_text: The principal question of law that falls to be determined in this writ petition filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India by the petitioner is which is tile appropriate Government-Central or the State Government- empowered to remit the sentence of a person companyvicted of

issues.text: Are the provisions of sections 489-A to 489-D, Penal Code, under which the petitioner was convicted, a law relating to a matter to which the legislative power of the State or the Union extends?

anchor.surface_text: Thus companysidered, it will resolve itself into the issue Are the provisions of sections 489-A to 489-D, Penal Code, under which the petitioner was companyvicted, a law relating to a matter to which the legislative power of the State or tile Union extends? These four sections

issues.text: Whether the entire Indian Penal Code, including sections 489-A to 489-D, falls under Entry No. 1 of the Concurrent List such that the excluding clause does not operate for these offences?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. Rao, learned Counsel for the petitioner, however, companytends that the entire Indian Penal Code, including sections 489-A to 489-D, as at the companymencement of the Constitution, would fall under the Head Criminal law, which finds a place in Entry No. 1 of the Concurrent List.

issues.text: Whether the Governor's G.O. No. Ms. 1321 under Article 161 granting remission applies to prisoners convicted under sections 489-A to 489-D IPC?

No. Ms. 1321, Home  Prisons A  Department, dated 25th September, 1969, granting special remission of sentences to various categories of prisoners mentioned therein.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner is entitled to the same treatment as other similarly placed prisoners who were released due to mistake by jail authorities?

arguments.claim: State Government has no power to remit the sentence of the petitioner as he was convicted of offences relating to a matter within the sphere of the executive power of the Union and not of the State.

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been opposed by the respondents on the ground that the State Government has nopower to remit the sentence of the petitioner, who was convicted of offences relating to a matter, which was within the sphere of the executive power of the Union and not of the State.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sections 489A-D relate to currency notes and bank notes under Entry 36 Union List and offences under Entry 93, hence within Union executive power per s402 CrPC.

arguments.claim: The four prisoners were released owing to a mistake by jail authorities and are liable to be remanded to undergo unexpired sentence if State Government cancels the remission.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been averred that the aforesaid four prisoners were released owing to a mistake on the part of the jail authorities and they are liable to be remanded to undergo the unexpired terms of their sentence, if the State Government cancels the remission granted to them by mistake,

arguments.claim: The entire Indian Penal Code including sections 489-A to 489-D falls under Entry 1 Concurrent List; the excluding clause operates only if no law made on List I/II matters, but Governor's G.O. is such a law so exclusion does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. Rao, learned Counsel for the petitioner, however, contends that the entire Indian Penal Code, including sections 489-A to 489-D, as at the commencement of the Constitution, would fall under the Head Criminal law, which finds a place in Entry No. 1 of the Concurrent List.

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 1 Concurrent List expressly excludes offences against laws on List I matters like currency (Entry 36) and such offences (Entry 93); exclusion applies regardless of specific laws made.

arguments.claim: The G.O. does not fall under head Criminal law per combined reading of Entry 1 List III and Entries 36/93 List I; even if assumed under Criminal law, proviso to Article 162 with Articles 72/73 prevents State executive power.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, Mr. Rama Reddy, learned counsel for the respondents, maintains that the G. 0. in question does not fall under the head Criminal law and that this position is crystal clear on a combined reading of Entry I of List III and Entries 36 and 93 of List 1.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ist in the same Schedule specifically companyfers on the Parliament the power to legislate with regard to offences against laws with respect to any of

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on Entries 36/93 placing matter in Union domain; Entry 1 excludes such offences.

arguments.claim: Even if State Government extended benefit of G.O. owing to mistake to four other similarly placed persons, it is not fair to deny the same treatment to the petitioner.
arguments.court_reasoning: Mistake by authorities does not confer right or bind government; no estoppel against statute.

arguments.claim: Provisions of sections 489-A to 489-D IPC under which petitioner convicted relate to matter (currency notes and bank notes) to which Union legislative power extends per Entry 36 and Entry 93 Union List.

anchor.surface_text: These four sections were added to the Penal Code under the caption, Of Currency Notes and Bank Notes, by Currency Notes Forgery Act, 1899, in order to make better provisions for the protection of Currency and Bank Notes against forgery.

arguments.claim: Entry 1 Concurrent List includes IPC but excludes offences against laws with respect to List I or II matters; ss 489A-D fall in exclusion as relating to Union List matters.

anchor.surface_text: Entry 1 of the Concurrent List reads thus Criminal law including all matters included in the Indian Penal Code at the commencement of this Constitution but excluding offences against laws with respect to any of the matters specified in List I or List II

arguments.claim: N. V. Natarajan case (Madras HC) is distinguishable as it concerned validity of state statute under different entries and not executive power limits for IPC offences or Governor's G.O.
Executive power of Union/State is co-extensive with respective legislative powers subject to Arts 73/162; distribution follows legislative per GOI Act 1935 analogy.

anchor.surface_text: As under the Government of India Act 1935, so under the Constitution, the distribution of executive powers follow, in substance, the distribution of legislative powers.

arguments.claim: G.O. Ms. 1321 preamble expressly limits to prisoners convicted of offences against laws relating to State executive power matters; ss489A-D are Union, so jail misinterpretation.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble of this G.O. expressly limits its operation to prisoners who are convicted of offences against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the State extends.

holdings.text: Read together, these entries put it beyond doubt that Currency Notes and Bank Notes, to which the offences under sections 489-A to 489-D relate, are matters which are exclusively within the legislative competence of the Union Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: Read together-, these entries put it beyond doubt that Currency Notes and Bank Notes, to which the offences under sections 489-A to 489-D relate, are matters which are exclusively within the legislative competence of the Union Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 489A-D added by Currency Notes Forgery Act 1899 under caption 'Of Currency Notes and Bank Notes'; currency, coinage, legal tender in Entry 36 Union List; offences against such laws in Entry 93 Union List.

holdings.text: It follows therefrom that the offences for which the petitioner has been convicted, are offences relating to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, and the appropriate Government competent to remit the sentence of the petitioner, would be the Central Government and not the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefrom that the offences for which the petitioner has been convicted, are offences relating to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, and the appropriate Government competent to remit the sentence of the petitioner, would be the Central Government and not the State Govern-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive power co-extensive with legislative power per Arts 73 & 162; s402(3) CrPC: Central Govt for offences against laws relating to Union executive matters.

holdings.text: This excluding clause in Entry No. 1, List III read with Entries Nos. 36 and 93 of the Union List, shows beyond all manner of doubt that in respect of offences falling under sections 489-A to 489-D, only the Central Government is competent to suspend or remit the sentence of a convict.

anchor.surface_text: This excluding clause in Entry No. 1, List III read with Entries Nos. 36 and 93 of the Union List, shows beyond all manner of doubt that in respect of offences falling under sections 489-A to 489-D, only the Central Government is competent to suspend or remit the sentence of a convict.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 1 Concurrent List includes IPC but expressly excludes offences against laws w.r.t. List I matters; exclusion operates independently of whether specific laws enacted; ss489A-D referable to Union List Entries 36 & 93.

holdings.text: The preamble of this G.O. expressly limits its operation to prisoners who are convicted of offences against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the State extends.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble of this G.O. expressly limits its operation to prisoners who are convicted of offences against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the State extends. The jail authorities obviously misinterpreting the aforesaid G-O.,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 161 limits Governor's pardoning power to state executive sphere; ss489A-D offences in Union sphere; jail authorities misinterpreted G.O. by applying to such prisoners.

holdings.text: As under the Government of India Act 1935, so under the Constitution, the distribution of executive powers follow, in substance, the distribution of legislative powers.

anchor.surface_text: As under the Government of India Act 1935, so under the Constitution, the distribution of executive powers follow, in substance, the distribution of legislative powers. The provisions primarily concerned with such distribution are to be found in Articles 73 and 162.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arts 73 & 162 make executive power co-extensive with legislative, subject to limitations; follows GOI Act 1935 precedent.

holdings.text: In N. V. Natarajans case supra, the High Court of Madras was considering the constitutional validity of section 5 of the Madras Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1957... The observations in N. V. Natarajans case, therefore, are of little assistance in determining the question before us.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Different facts and issues: state statute validity under List II vs. executive power limits for IPC offences under s401 CrPC and Art 161.

precedents.cited_proposition: the exclusion by the words 'excluding offences against laws with respect to any of the matters specified in List I or List II' does not operate to limit the ambit of Criminal law until a law is made with respect to such matters
precedents.cited_holding: Our understanding of the effect of the exclusion... till a law is made with respect to any of the matters, in List I or List II, no limit is placed upon and the exclusion does not operate to limit the ambit of the power under the head of Criminal law in List III.
